name: summary_title_plot
system_prompt:
You are an assistant tasked with comparing three lists of movies. For each movie, you are given its: title, plot
Your main goal is to assign a diversity score to each list based on the given information.
Use your own judgment to determine what information is relevant when assessing the diversity of the lists. 
You should consider the given title, plot for every movie, as well as an overall summary of the entire list.

The summary includes the following information:
    - Popularity Diversity: A score based on the mix of blockbuster movies and niche/independent films. The higher the score, the more balanced is the list.
    - Genre Diversity: A score based on the variety of genres represented in the list. The higher the score, the more diverse the genres.
    - Theme Diversity: A score based on the thematic range of the movies in the list. The higher the score, the more varied and expansive the themes across the movies in the list.
    - Time Span: Years of the earliest and latest movie releases in the list.
    - Franchise Inclusion: Whether the list includes at least two movies from the same franchise.

Deliver your descriptions of lists, comparison, and choice of the most diverse list in the following JSON format:

{
    "list_A_description": string,            # Describe the diversity of the movies in list A, focusing on and utilizing the information provided in the summary.
    "list_B_description": string,            # Describe the diversity of the movies in list B, focusing on and utilizing the information provided in the summary.
    "list_C_description": string,            # Describe the diversity of the movies in list C, focusing on and utilizing the information provided in the summary.
    "comparison": string,                    # Compare the diversity of the lists.
    "diversity_scores": dict                 # A dictionary assigning a diversity score (0-10) to each list based on its relative diversity. Example: {"A": 5, "B": 2, "C": 10} (where C is the most diverse and B the least).
}

evaluations.prompt:
List A:
TITLE: Big Hero 6 (2014)
PLOT: A special bond develops between plus-sized inflatable robot Baymax and prodigy Hiro Hamada, who together team up with a group of friends to form a band of high-tech heroes.

TITLE: Others, The (2001)
PLOT: In 1945, immediately following the end of Second World War, a woman who lives with her two photosensitive children on her darkened old family estate in the Channel Islands becomes convinced that the home is haunted.

TITLE: Catch Me If You Can (2002)
PLOT: Barely 21 yet, Frank is a skilled forger who has passed as a doctor, lawyer and pilot. FBI agent Carl becomes obsessed with tracking down the con man, who only revels in the pursuit.

TITLE: Meet the Parents (2000)
PLOT: Male nurse Greg Focker meets his girlfriend's parents before proposing, but her suspicious father is every date's worst nightmare.

TITLE: Whiplash (2014)
PLOT: A promising young drummer enrolls at a cut-throat music conservatory where his dreams of greatness are mentored by an instructor who will stop at nothing to realize a student's potential.

TITLE: Super Size Me (2004)
PLOT: While examining the influence of the fast food industry, Morgan Spurlock personally explores the consequences on his health of a diet of solely McDonald's food for one month.

TITLE: Patriot, The (2000)
PLOT: Peaceful farmer Benjamin Martin is driven to lead the Colonial Militia during the American Revolution when a sadistic British officer murders his son.

TITLE: Office Space (1999)
PLOT: Three company workers who hate their jobs decide to rebel against their greedy boss.



Summary:
Popularity Diversity: The list contains a mix of popular movies like Big Hero 6 and Meet the Parents, and less popular/niche movies like The Others and Office Space. Therefore, it does not lean heavily on one side of the popularity spectrum.
Genre Diversity: The movies in the list span a wide range of genres, including animation, action, horror, mystery, thriller, biography, crime, drama, comedy, romance, documentary, history and war. There is a significant variety of genres represented.
Theme Diversity: The movies explore diverse themes such as family relationships (Big Hero 6, Meet the Parents), psychological horror (The Others), ambition and deception (Catch Me If You Can), rebellion against authority (Office Space), dedication and mentorship (Whiplash), social commentary (Super Size Me), war and patriotism (The Patriot). While there's variety, some themes like ambition or family relationships appear in more than one movie.
Time Span: The earliest movie is Office Space (1999), and the latest is Big Hero 6 and Whiplash (2014).
Franchise Inclusion: No - There are no movies in this list that belong to the same franchise.

List B:
TITLE: Bourne Identity, The (2002)
PLOT: A man is picked up by a fishing boat, bullet-riddled and suffering from amnesia, before racing to elude assassins and attempting to regain his memory.

TITLE: Bourne Supremacy, The (2004)
PLOT: When Jason Bourne is framed for a CIA operation gone awry, he is forced to resume his former life as a trained assassin to survive.

TITLE: Guardians of the Galaxy 2 (2017)
PLOT: The Guardians struggle to keep together as a team while dealing with their personal family issues, notably Star-Lord's encounter with his father, the ambitious celestial being Ego.

TITLE: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)
PLOT: A soldier fighting aliens gets to relive the same day over and over again, the day restarting every time he dies.

TITLE: Iron Man (2008)
PLOT: After being held captive in an Afghan cave, billionaire engineer Tony Stark creates a unique weaponized suit of armor to fight evil.

TITLE: Catch Me If You Can (2002)
PLOT: Barely 21 yet, Frank is a skilled forger who has passed as a doctor, lawyer and pilot. FBI agent Carl becomes obsessed with tracking down the con man, who only revels in the pursuit.

TITLE: Others, The (2001)
PLOT: In 1945, immediately following the end of Second World War, a woman who lives with her two photosensitive children on her darkened old family estate in the Channel Islands becomes convinced that the home is haunted.

TITLE: Batman Begins (2005)
PLOT: After witnessing his parents' death, Bruce learns the art of fighting to confront injustice. When he returns to Gotham as Batman, he must stop a secret society that intends to destroy the city.



Summary:
Popularity Diversity: The list contains a mix of blockbuster movies (Iron Man, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2, Batman Begins) and less popular films (The Others, Catch Me If You Can). The Bourne movies are somewhere in between, so the diversity is moderate.
Genre Diversity: The list includes several action movies but also movies from other genres, such as horror, biography, and comedy.  Genre diversity is moderate because action and thriller are repeated across several movies.
Theme Diversity: The movies explore a range of themes including identity (Bourne series), family (Guardians of the Galaxy), fighting injustice (Batman), con artistry (Catch Me If You Can), and the supernatural (The Others). However, some themes, like action and suspense, are repeated, leading to moderate theme diversity.
Time Span: The earliest movie is The Others (2001), and the latest is Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 (2017).
Franchise Inclusion: Yes - The list includes multiple movies from the Jason Bourne franchise (The Bourne Identity, The Bourne Supremacy).

PLOT: The Guardians struggle to keep together as a team while dealing with their personal family issues, notably Star-Lord's encounter with his father, the ambitious celestial being Ego.

Summary:

Genre Diversity: The list covers genres such as Action, Adventure, Sci-Fi, Thriller, Mystery, Horror, Biography, Crime, and Drama. While diverse, some genres like Action and Thriller are repeated across multiple movies.
Theme Diversity: The movies explore themes of family, identity, revenge, justice, isolation, and the supernatural.  Some thematic overlaps exist, such as the focus on action and suspense in several films.
Time Span: The earliest movie is The Others (2001), and the latest is Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 (2017).
Franchise Inclusion: Yes - The list includes two movies from the Bourne franchise: The Bourne Identity and The Bourne Supremacy, as well as two movies from the Marvel Cinematic Universe: Iron Man and Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a good balance of popularity, with both critically acclaimed and mainstream movies included.  Its genre diversity is excellent, covering animation, horror, mystery, thriller, biography, crime, drama, comedy, romance, documentary, and war.  Thematic diversity is also strong, exploring family, ambition, deception, rebellion, mentorship, social commentary, and war, although some themes overlap. The time span covers 1999-2014, and there is no franchise inclusion.
response.list_B_description: List B has a moderate level of popularity diversity, mixing blockbusters with less mainstream films. Genre diversity is moderate, with a focus on action and thriller genres. Theme diversity is also moderate, with themes of identity, family, fighting injustice, and the supernatural, but some repetition. The time span is 2001-2017, and it includes the Bourne franchise.
response.list_C_description: List C is similar to List B in terms of popularity and genre diversity, with a mix of blockbusters and less popular films, and a focus on action and thriller. Theme diversity is moderate, with some thematic overlap. The time span is 2001-2017, and it includes both the Bourne and Marvel franchises.
response.comparison: List A stands out due to its superior genre and thematic diversity compared to Lists B and C. While Lists B and C contain popular movies and some genre variety, they lack the breadth of genres and themes present in List A.  Lists B and C also suffer from franchise repetition, which List A avoids.  List A's time span is slightly shorter, but this is a minor factor compared to the significant differences in genre and thematic diversity.

response.list_C_description: List C exhibits the highest diversity among the three lists. evaluations.prompt:
List A:

PLOT: Following the Normandy Landings, a group of U.S. soldiers go behind enemy lines to retrieve a paratrooper whose brothers have been killed in action.

TITLE: Aferim! (2015)
PLOT: Set in early 19th century Romania, a policeman, Costandin, is hired by a nobleman to find a Gypsy slave who has run away from his estate after having an affair with his wife.

TITLE: Open Season: Scared Silly (2016)
PLOT: Elliot, Boog and all of the beloved woodland creatures are back in a brand-new comedy adventure.

TITLE: SuperFly (2018)
PLOT: With retirement on his mind, a successful Atlanta-based drug dealer sets up one last big job while dealing with trigger-happy colleagues and the police.

TITLE: The Miniaturist (2017)
PLOT: A young woman moves to 17th century Amsterdam and hires a mysterious local miniaturist to furnish the dollhouse she received from her merchant husband as a present, but the lifelike miniatures somehow start eerily foreshadowing her fate.

TITLE: Hannah Montana & Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert (2008)
PLOT: A 3-D concert film of the 2007 Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus tour.

TITLE: Take the L (2017)
PLOT: A day in the life of two best friends, a drug dealer, and a store manager collide at a hip-hop concert in the Inland Empire.

TITLE: Tanu Weds Manu (2011)
PLOT: Manu comes to India to find a bride and falls for Tanu at first sight, but free-spirited Tanu has no plan to marry him.

Popularity Diversity: The list contains a mix of popular movies like Saving Private Ryan and niche films like Aferim! and The Miniaturist
Genre Diversity: The movies span a wide range of genres, including war, adventure, comedy, animation, crime, thriller, fantasy, mystery, documentary, and romance.  Most movies have unique genres not repeated across other films in the list
Theme Diversity: While the themes are varied, some overlap exists. For example, 'struggle' is present in Saving Private Ryan, Aferim!, and Superfly; 'love' is present in Tanu Weds Manu and perhaps subtly in The Miniaturist.
Time Span: The earliest movie is Saving Private Ryan (1998), and the latest is Superfly (2018).
Franchise Inclusion: No - There are no movies from the same franchise in this list.

Theme Diversity: The movies explore various themes such as war (Saving Private Ryan), love (Mr. & Mrs. Smith, Pirates of the Caribbean), crime (Goodfellas, Mr. & Mrs. Smith), artificial intelligence (Ex Machina), adventure (Pirates of the Caribbean, Up, Monsters, Inc.), and family relationships (Up, Monsters, Inc.). The diversity of themes is high, resulting in a score of 3.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a good balance between popular and niche films.  The genre diversity is high, with representation from war, drama, comedy, animation, crime, and romance.  While some thematic overlap exists (e.g., struggle, love), the overall thematic range is quite broad. The time span covers two decades (1998-2018), and there is no franchise inclusion.

response.list_C_description: List C features a blend of blockbuster and less mainstream films, offering a good level of popularity diversity. response.comparison: List A and List B have similar popularity diversity, but List A has significantly higher genre and thematic diversity. List C stands out with its strong popularity, genre, and thematic diversity, and the inclusion of movies from the same franchise adds another layer of interest.  List A is more diverse than List B, but List C surpasses both in terms of overall diversity.

PLOT: The modern-day descendant of Little Red Riding Hood brings her fiancĂ© home to meet her family and reveal their occupation as werewolf hunters, but after he is bitten by a werewolf, she must protect him from her own family.

TITLE: Still Bill (2009)
PLOT: A portrait of soul legend Bill Withers.

TITLE: Beneath Hill 60 (2010)
PLOT: In 1916, the 1st Australian Tunnelling Company is tunneling beneath German fortifications and bunkers to detonate massive explosive charges.

TITLE: Comedy Central Roast of Charlie Sheen (2011)
PLOT: It's Charlie Sheen's turn to step in to the celebrity hot seat for the latest installment of The Comedy Central Roast.

TITLE: Flightplan (2005)
PLOT: A bereaved woman and her daughter are flying home from Berlin to America. At 30,000 feet, the child vanishes, and nobody will admit she was ever on the plane.

TITLE: Major League (1989)
PLOT: The new owner of the Cleveland Indians puts together a purposely horrible team so they'll lose and she can move the team. But when the plot is uncovered, they start winning just to spite her.

Genre Diversity: The movies in this list span a wide range of genres including Action, Adventure, Crime, Drama, Sci-Fi, Thriller, Animation, Short, Comedy, Family, Romance, Fantasy, Horror, Documentary, Biography, Music, Mystery, Sport, and War.  The diversity in genres results in a score of 3.
Theme Diversity: The movies explore diverse themes such as family relationships ('See You Yesterday', 'Paperman'), the supernatural ('Red: Werewolf Hunter'), music biography ('Still Bill'), war ('Beneath Hill 60'), comedy ('Major League', 'Comedy Central Roast of Charlie Sheen'), mystery and suspense ('Flightplan'). The variety of themes earns a score of 3.
Time Span: The earliest movie is Major League (1989), and the latest is See You Yesterday (2019).
Franchise Inclusion: No - There are no movies from the same franchise in this list.

PLOT: Frankie, an ill-tempered old coach, reluctantly agrees to train aspiring boxer Maggie. Impressed with her determination and talent, he helps her become the best and the two soon form a close bond.

PLOT: A former Roman General sets out to exact vengeance against the corrupt emperor who murdered his family and sent him into slavery.

Genre Diversity: The list includes a variety of genres such as Action, Sci-Fi, Comedy, Drama, and more. However, some genres like Action and Drama are repeated across multiple movies.
Theme Diversity: The movies cover themes of revenge, adventure, love, friendship, and more.  However, some themes like adventure and revenge are repeated.
Time Span: The earliest movie is Police Academy 5: Assignment: Miami Beach (1988) and the latest is Looper (2012).
Franchise Inclusion: Yes - The list includes at least two movies from the Harry Potter franchise.

List C:
TITLE: Inside Out (2015)
PLOT: After young Riley is uprooted from her Midwest life and moved to San Francisco, her emotions - Joy, Fear, Anger, Disgust, and Sadness - conflict on how best to navigate a new city, house, and school.

TITLE: Blade II (2002)
PLOT: Blade forms an uneasy alliance with the vampire council in order to combat the Reapers, who are feeding on vampires.

TITLE: Step Up (2006)
PLOT: Tyler Gage receives the opportunity of a lifetime after vandalizing a performing arts school, gaining him the chance to earn a scholarship and dance with an up and coming dancer, Nora.

TITLE: Hotel Rwanda (2004)
PLOT: Paul Rusesabagina, a hotel manager, houses over a thousand Tutsi refugees during their struggle against the Hutu militia in Rwanda, Africa.

TITLE: Hangover, The (2009)
PLOT: Three buddies wake up from a bachelor party in Las Vegas, with no memory of the previous night and the bachelor missing. They make their way around the city in order to find their friend before his wedding.

PLOT: Frankie, an ill-tempered old coach, reluctantly agrees to train aspiring boxer Maggie. Impressed with her determination and talent, he helps her become the best and the two soon form a close bond.

PLOT: A skilled London police officer, after irritating superiors with his embarrassing effectiveness, is transferred to a village where the easygoing officers object to his fervor for regulations, as a string of grisly murders strikes the town.

TITLE: There Will Be Blood (2007)
PLOT: A story of family, religion, hatred, oil and madness, focusing on a turn-of-the-century prospector in the early days of the business.

Popularity Diversity: The list includes a mix of popular movies (e.g., The Hangover) and less mainstream films (e.g., Hotel Rwanda, There Will Be Blood).  Therefore, the popularity diversity score is 2.
Genre Diversity: The movies span a wide range of genres, including animation, action, horror, sci-fi, thriller, crime, drama, music, romance, biography, history, war, comedy, mystery, sport.  There is a considerable level of genre diversity; therefore the score is 3.
Theme Diversity: The movies explore various themes such as family relationships (Inside Out), redemption (Million Dollar Baby), violence (Blade II, Hot Fuzz), social issues (Hotel Rwanda), friendship (The Hangover), ambition (There Will Be Blood). While diverse, some themes like drama and overcoming challenges repeat. Therefore, the theme diversity score is 2.

Franchise Inclusion: No - There are no movies from the same franchise in this list.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a broad range of genres and themes, from animation (Paperman) and documentaries (Still Bill) to action (Flightplan) and comedy (Major League).  The time span is significant, covering movies from 1989 to 2019. The inclusion of both popular and less mainstream films contributes to its diversity.  The lack of franchise movies doesn't detract from its overall variety.
response.list_B_description: List B has a good mix of popular and less popular films, but the genre and thematic diversity is less pronounced than List A.  While it includes genres like sci-fi (Looper), comedy (The Hangover), and drama (Million Dollar Baby), the repetition of certain themes (revenge, adventure) limits its thematic range. The inclusion of movies from the Harry Potter franchise adds a franchise element, but doesn't necessarily enhance overall diversity.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a blend of popular and less mainstream movies, similar to List A.  The genre diversity is high, encompassing animation (Inside Out), action (Blade II), and drama (Hotel Rwanda). Thematically, the list explores family, redemption, social issues, and ambition, showcasing a decent level of thematic variety.  The absence of franchise movies further contributes to its diverse nature.
response.comparison: List A and List C demonstrate greater diversity than List B.  List B, while containing a mix of popular and less popular films, suffers from less thematic and genre variety compared to the other two lists. List A stands out for its exceptionally wide range of genres, while List C offers a strong balance of popular and less mainstream films with a good spread of themes.  List A's broader genre range gives it a slight edge over List C.

PLOT: In 1976, Karen and Barry Mason had fallen on hard times and were looking for a way to support their young family when they answered an ad in the Los Angeles Times. Larry Flynt was seeking distributors for Hustler Magazine. What was expected to be a brief sideline led to their becoming fully immersed in the LGBT community as they took over a local store, Circus of Books. A decade later, they had become the biggest distributors of gay porn in the US. The film focuses on the double life they led, trying to maintain the balance of being parents at a time when LGBT culture was not yet accepted. Their many challenges included facing jail time for a federal obscenity prosecution and enabling their store to be a place of refuge at the height of the AIDS crisis. Circus of Books offers a rare glimpse into an untold chapter of queer history, and it is told through the lens of the owners' own daughter, Rachel Mason, an artist, filmmaker and musician.

PLOT: "The Trials of Darryl Hunt" is a feature documentary about a brutal rape/murder case and a wrongly convicted man, Darryl Hunt, who spent nearly twenty years in prison for a crime he did not commit. Both a social justice story and a personally driven narrative, the film chronicles this capital case from 1984 through 2004. With exclusive footage from two decades, the film frames the judicial and emotional response to a chilling crime - and the implications that reverberate from Hunt's conviction - against a backdrop of class and racial bias in the South and in the American criminal justice system. This documentary is the culmination of ten years of research and filming. In 1993, inspired by claims of injustice and police conspiracy, the filmmakers began to shoot in North Carolina. Working from a mix of formats (16mm and 24P video) the film melds the visceral reality of a murder case with first person accounts and cinematic imagery, illuminating perceptions and memories of events as they unfolded for the people closest to this haunting story. This unique look at one man's loss and redemption challenges the assumption that all Americans have the right to unbiased justice. Hunt's story - while one man's personal journey - reflects systemic issues of national concern: cross-racial eyewitness identification, prosecutorial misconduct, inexperienced defense attorneys assigned to capital cases, racial bias in death penalty cases and errors in police procedure. Barry Scheck from The Innocence Project, who worked on Hunt's case for ten years, and Gary Wells, professor and eyewitness expert, offer concrete examples where errors occurred in Hunt's saga and offer future remedies and effective ideas to prevent future "Darryl Hunts." Hunt himself addresses the need for systemic reforms to prevent wrongful convictions, underscoring the haunting reality that Hunt could have been sentenced to death and we would never have known this story.â€”Annie Sundberg
